guide_block.new_en_block:
## How It Works

### How to Use

Enter coordinates and Aurora Capture will automatically use your local time and time zone to generate an observing briefing.

**ã€Nowã€‘**
Updated every 10 minutes to answer:
â€œShould I head out now? Is it worth setting up?â€

**ã€Next 3 Hoursã€‘**
Shows hour-by-hour conditions and highlights the best hour to observe.
Also indicates whether auroral activity is building, peaking, or fading, and answers:
â€œIs it worth staying on watch over the next 3 hours?â€

**ã€Next 3 Daysã€‘**
Incorporates additional CH and CME information to assess auroral activity on a day-by-day basis.
From a broader data perspective, it answers:
â€œWhich day in the next 3 days is most worth planning for?â€

### Why Not Just Kp?

Kp is a broad, global index designed for monitoring space weather at scale.

It is highly useful for spacecraft operations, power-grid protection, and long-term geomagnetic disturbance assessment.

But Kp was never designed to serve a ground observer who cares about a specific location and a specific time window.

For aurora observing and photography, Kp is often too coarse.

It does not capture rapid changes in the IMF direction, and it struggles to reflect short-term stability and local responses.

This is why real-world experience can look like this:
Kp seems â€œperfectâ€ on paper, yet nothing is observable or photographable.

That is how Aurora Capture was bornâ€”on a -40Â°C night in Mohe.

The C value (Capture Index) is not meant to replace Kp.
It is closer to a â€œphotographability indexâ€ built for photographers and chasers.

As a landscape photographer with an engineering background, I started from an observerâ€™s perspective:
I model directly from raw solar wind and magnetic-field parameters,
and evaluateâ€”on shorter time scalesâ€”whether they are forming a window that is friendly for shooting.

Letâ€™s take a look at what kind of hand Earth is holding right now.

Should you head out now? Get an instant observing window.
Notice: We recommend using â€œGet current locationâ€. You can also enter coordinates manually.
Notice: To get destination coordinates, right-click a point in Google Maps to copy the latitude and longitude. You can also use any online coordinate picker.
Higher C values indicate stronger justification for committing time and effort.
High expected return; immediate action is recommended.
Conditions are favorable; preparation and test shots are recommended.
A possible window exists; set up and wait for triggering conditions.
Unlikely to See. Try only at low cost.
Not recommended to commit resources during this time window.
Note: A surge does not guarantee observability; cloud cover and sky brightness still apply.
A day-by-day outlook for the next three days, designed to help with trip planning and time allocation.
Strong background energy and favorable delivery conditions. Suitable for advance planning.
Moderate-to-good conditions. Planning may be worthwhile, depending on location and clouds.
Weak overall conditions. Advance planning is generally not justified.
Overall conditions are weak. Advance planning is not worthwhile.
Very weak background and delivery conditions. Planning is not recommended.

Maintained personally; replies may be delayed.

NOAA data definitions have changed, or some fields are missing:
Forecast reliability is currently low. Please interpret with caution.
Please enter a valid email address.
You are near the primary oval region (higher chance of being overhead / at high elevation).
You are closer to the primary oval region (higher chance of being overhead / at high elevation).
You are in the outer visibility zone: expect low-elevation northern aurora and higher-altitude glow; outcomes depend heavily on clouds and sky brightness.
You are far from the primary oval region: it becomes an edge-horizon gamble and requires stronger triggering or longer duration.
The system is more likely to activate, but not yet in sustained triggering.
There was a recent disturbance; after-effects may persist for a while.
Background is insufficient or triggering is unclear.
Cloud cover is blocking the sky; not favorable for observing.
The sky is bright; faint aurora may be hard to see.
Energy input is weak; effective aurora is unlikely.
